abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome was satisfactory,
            with a highly likely sustainability, and high institutional
            development impacts. Lessons on project design, and policy
            implications suggest that: although project companies
            improved performance, sustained improvements require
            profound institutional, and regulatory reform, because
            performance agreements did not provide incentives for the
            utilities, nor did loan proceeds help in striving for better
            performance, and, the supply-driven nature of sub-borrower
            selection hindered further performance improvements. In
            addition, there was a degree of disconnect between the
            institutional, and investment components, because although
            limited technical assistance was provided under the
            institutional component, it stopped short of providing
            further support for implementation of complementary
            regulatory reform. Based on these lessons, in the follow-up
            project, participating utilities shall be selected based on
            demand. Lessons on project implementation indicate that:
            difficulties encountered with the Bank's procurement
            guidelines, were minimized by a workshop organized by the
            supervision team, which helped accelerate the procurement
            process. However, the terms of reference for consulting
            services on operational development programs, or the tariff
            studies, could have been developed during preparation, to
            avoid contract delays. And, despite the originally foreseen
            creation of a Federal technical team, to manage the
            institutional component, delays of the investment component
            hampered expected benefits among the public companies;
            instead, the Federal management unit could have facilitated
            learning, and introduced competitive mechanisms among those companies.

abstracts.cdata!:
The modernization of the water supply
            and sanitation sector is the first priority of the Ministry
            of Social Action (MAS) and the National Secretariat for
            Water Supply and Sanitation (SNS).  The main project
            objectives are : i) to strengthen the sector's
            institutional capabilities; ii) to help Companhia
            Catarinense de Aguas e Saneamento (CASAN), Empresa Baiana de
            Aguas e Saneamento S.A. (EMBASA), and Empresa de Saneamento
            do Mato Grosso do Sol (SANESUL) to operate on a commercial
            basis, with financial self-sufficiency, corporate autonomy,
            and accountability for their actions; and iii) to improve
            environmental and health conditions in urban areas, through
            the expansion of water supply and sewerage services.
            Project components include : a) the formulation of a new
            regulatory framework for the water and wastes sector; b) the
            evaluation and reformulation of the sector investment
            programming and financing framework, aiming at upgrading its
            efficiency and ensuring an improvement in the self-financing
            of sector companies; c) technical assistance and training to
            increase their institutional capacity to carry out their
            responsibilities; d) training of sector management; e)
            preparation facilities for a proposed Water Demand
            Management and Systems Rehabilitation Project; and f)
            financing the expansion and reinforcement of the water
            supply and sewerage systems of CASAN, EMBASA, and SANESUL,
            improving their operational efficiency and quality of their service.

735556.subtopic:
Town Water Supply and Sanitation,Environmental Economics & Policies,Health Economics & Finance,Water Supply and Sanitation Governance
